INTRODUCTION



The Tembec BTLSR Inc facility (Tembec BTLSR)  utilizes more than the threshold quantity of formaldehyde solution (14,600 gallons) in the resin manufacturing process, therefore, this facility is required to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) as defined in A?68.150. 



The Tembec BTLSR facility is also subject to OSHA's PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and public receptors are located within the worst-case release scenario for the plant. Therefore, the facility is subject to Program 3 requirements. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in USEPA's RMP Rule. All elements required by USEPA's 40 CFR 68 - Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM. 



Tembec BTLSR first submitted a RMP to USEPA in 1999.  RMP's must be updated and resubmitted to USEPA every five (5) years.  The following information summarizes the Tembec BTLSR 2015 update and resubmission.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 



Tembec BTLSR maintains a policy of safe resin manufacturing operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with the manufacturing processes, and reducing any subsequent risk to the surrounding community, their employees, and the environment.   



The Tembec BTLSR facility has procedures in place, including both onsite activities and coordination with offsite responders that are to be followed in the event of a formaldehyde leak.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND SUBSTANCE HANDLED



Tembec BTLSR facility consists of three main locations where formaldehyde (45% by weight solution) is handled: unloading area outside the facility; a storage tank, and; reactors in which formaldehyde is mixed with urea or melamine to manufacture liquid resins.  

 

The formaldehyde solution is delivered to Tembec BTLSR by tanker truck and is stored in a single storage tank, which is only filled when an entire delivery can be received due to administrative controls.  



The facility also includes liquid feed

piping, miscellaneous valves, secondary containment and a scrubber system.  





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The accident history for Tembec BTLSR was reviewed for the period from Jan 2010  through Jan 2015.  During this period of time, 2 accidental releases of formaldehyde solution occurred that resulted in NO deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or any environmental impact.  The 2 releases during this time frame were small quantities, <50 lbs and handled by internal clean-up and proper disposal procedures.







ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Tembec BTLSR maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of formaldehyde solution.  As previously indicated, the Prevention Program required under 40 CFR Part 68 is identical to the prevention program required under OSHA PSM. Required elements include

 

1. Employee Participation

Tembec BTLSR attempts to ensure employees and their representatives actively participate in the risk management program.  As noted, employees participated in the process hazard analysis and compliance audit.



2. Process Safety Information

Tembec BTLSR has maintained information concerning process chemicals, technology, and equipment as part of their risk management program at the facility.  The information is made available to employees and contractors who will work in or about the formaldehyde solution process area.  Emergency response planners can also use the information to develop training programs and procedures.



3. Process Hazard Analysis

A process hazard analysis (PHA) of the formaldehyde solution processes and procedures is conducted at least every five (5) years to evaluate potential causes and consequences of accidental releases.  A PHA was facilitated by internal trained employee using the What If/Checklist method with the assistance of Tembec BTLSR plant management a

nd staff familiar with the process, operations and maintenance activities at the facility in June 2014.  The results of this review identified a number of changes in operating, maintenance, and other process safety management procedures that would improve the overall safety of the facility.



4. Operating Procedures

Tembec BTLSR has developed and implemented operating procedures that provide instructions and step for conducting activities associated with the formaldehyde solution processes consistent with the safety information.  BTLSR operating procedures include startup, shutdown, temporary, and emergency operating procedures, and describe how the system should be operated in order to minimize the chances of an accidental release.  The procedures also empha safety considerations during operation and address hazardous situations that can occur and how to correct them.



5. Training

All Tembec BTLSR staff currently involved in formaldehyde solution processes have been trained in the classroom and/or during on-the-job training in an overview of the processes and in the operating procedures, as is new staff assigned to the processes.  Training includes emphasis on safety and health, hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years to ensure Tembec BTLSR staff understands and adheres to current operating procedures.  



5. Contractors

Tembec BTLSR has a contractor safety program for all operations at the facility, including on or near the formaldehyde solution process.



6. Pre-startup Review

There have been approximately a half dozen changes to the Tembec BTLSR facility that has required a pre-startup safety review.  These reviews involved adding a check valve to the piping system to prevent backflow into the formaldehyde measuring device.  Also, some piping modifications to remove unused portions of the formaldehyde system were made.  All future necessary changes will be acco

mpanied by a review that will be performed following criteria identified in the Tembec BTLSR risk management program.



7. Mechanical Integrity

Tembec BTLSR has a preventive and corrective maintenance program to ensure equipment used to process, store, or handle formaldehyde solution is functioning properly and installed to minimize the risk of releases.  The program will address equipment testing, inspection, and preventive maintenance schedules, and documentation of equipment testing, inspection, and preventive and corrective maintenance activities. Thickness testing frequencies have been adjusted to follow industry standards.  Also, an internal PM program organizes and documents the facilities PSM - RMP related maintenance activities.



8. Hot Work

Tembec BTLSR has a hot work permit system in place for all hot work operations at the facility, including on or near the formaldehyde solution process.



9. Management of Change

Tembec BTLSR has written procedures to manage changes to formaldehyde solution processes, equipment and procedures.  As with pre-safety start-ups, approximately 1/2 dozen MOC's have been performed between 2010 and 2015.



10. Incident Investigation

Tembec BTLSR management investigates each incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a release of formaldehyde solution.  A process to identify the underlying causes of incidents and implement procedures for preventing similar events has been developed. 



An incident investigation team will be established following criteria established in the Tembec BTLSR risk management program.  As part of the investigation, an incident report will be prepared to recommend system changes (i.e., operational modifications, additional training and competency requirements), to prevent a similar incident from occurring in the future.  The incident investigation report and any changes resulting from the report will be reviewed with all staff members who operate and maintain the applicable sy

stem.



11. Compliance audits

USEPA's risk management rule requires that Tembec BTLSR complete a compliance audit for its risk management program at least once every 3 years.  The primary goals of conducting a compliance audit are to verify compliance with risk management rule requirements and good process safety practices, identify process safety or program deficiencies and develop corrective actions, and increase safety awareness among Tembec BTLSR staff.  An internal audit, was performed by a trained internal employee (with the aid and approval of an OSHA review of compliance audit procedures)in June 2012.  A complete PHA was completed in Nov. 2014.  The next planned internal audit date will occur before July 2015.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



Tembec BTLSR has an Emergency Action Plan in place that outlines the actions required to respond to a formaldehyde emergency.  The Emergency Action Plan meets the exception listed in 40 CFR 68.90 (b), and therefore the facility is not required to have the Emergency Response Program of 40 CFR 68.95.   The facility has coordinated the plan with the Lucas County LEPC and the Toledo Fire Department, and is included in the written community response plan.  The Toledo Fire Department is designated as the first responders in the event of more than an incidental formaldehyde solution release.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Recommendations for safety improvements were identified in the Process Hazard Analysis which was conducted in June 2014.  All safety improvements have been made.  Additional recommendations may be made upon review of any accidents and/or when the Process Hazard Analysis is updated every five years or when a major process change is made.
